title-group.article-title: Rediscovery of a Deep-sea Fish Parasite Lophoura cornuta (Copepoda: Sphyriidae) in the Western North Pacific off Hokkaido, Northern Japan

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Rediscovery of a Deep-sea Fish Parasite
Lophoura cornuta
( Copepoda : Sphyriidae ) in the Western North Pacific off Hokkaido , Northern Japan
Kazuya Nagasawa 1 ,2

1
Graduate School of Integrated Sciences for Life, Hiroshima University, 1-4-4 Kagamiyama, Higashi-Hiroshima, Hiroshima 739-8528, Japan E-mail: ornatus@hiroshima-u.ac.jp 2
Aquaparasitology Laboratory, 365-61 Kusanagi, Shizuoka 424-0886, Japan
(Received 18 October 2023 ; Accepted 28 November 2023 )

Two post-metamorphic adult females of the sphyriid copepod
Lophoura cornuta (C. B. Wilson, 1919 )
were collected from Kaup’s arrowtooth eel
Synaphobranchus kaupii Johnson, 1862
( Anguilliformes : Synaphobranchidae ) at two deep-sea sites in the western North Pacific off the south coast of Hokkaido , northern Japan . This paper reports on the morphology of
L. cornuta
based on the adult female specimens collected as the second record of the species from Japan . One of the collection sites is near the type locality of the parasite, and the infected fish were captured at depths of 550 and 620 m on the continental slope. Although the type host of
L. cornuta
was reported as “
Synaphobranchus affinis Günther, 1877
”, this fish may be
S. kaupii
because the latter species predominates among synaphobranchid eels in the western North Pacific off Hokkaido . An identification key to the four nominal species of the genus
Lophoura Kӧlliker
in
1853 reported from Japan is also provided.
Key Words: parasitic copepod , mesoparasite , deep-sea fish parasite , key to species , synaphobranchid eels .

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The sphyriid copepod
Lophoura cornuta (C. B. Wilson, 1919 )
is a parasite of deep-sea fishes of the two anguilliform families,
Synaphobranchidae ( Boxshall and Halsey 2004 )
and
Congridae ( Sebone and Dippenaar 2023 )
. To date, there are only three occurrence records of this parasite each from Japan , New Caledonia , and South Africa (
;
;
). It was originally described as
Rebelula cornuta
by
based on one post-metamorphic female with a dwarf male attached from a grey cutthroat
Synaphobranchus affinis Günther, 1877
in the western North Pacific off Cape Ochiishi (report- ed as “Oichiishi Saki”), eastern Hokkaido , northern Japan . Later, this copepod was transferred by
to the genus
Lophoura Kӧlliker
in
, and redescribed by
using three adult female specimens from another synaphobranchid eel
Synaphobranchus cf. brevidorsalis Günther, 1877
caught in the western South Pacific off New Caledonia . Recently,
L. cornuta
was reported from one female specimen taken from a hairy conger
Bassanago albescens (Barnard, 1923)
in the Indian Ocean off the south coast of South Africa (
). As
L. cornuta
was found “from the flesh on the side of ” the fish (
) or “embedded in the flanks of the eel” (
), it is a mesoparasite (sensu
). According to
, only part of the neck and the trunk of
L. cornuta
protrudes externally, and the cephalothorax and neck of the species pass through the host’s body musculature into the body cavity.

Two specimens of parasitic copepod taken from Kaup’s arrowtooth eel
Synaphobranchus kaupii Johnson, 1862
in the western North Pacific off the south coast of Hokkaido were previously sent to me by the staff of the Hokkaido Fisheries Experimental Station and are currently identified as
L. cornuta
. In this paper, I redescribe
L. cornuta
from the two specimens as the second record of the species from Japan . An identification key to the four nominal species of the genus
Lophoura
reported from Japan is also provided.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Two copepod specimens were collected from Kaup’s arrowtooth eel captured in bottom trawls at two locations in the western North Pacific: off Cape Shirepa, eastern Hokkaido on 24 March 1983 and off Shin-Hidaka, central Hokkaido on 21 August 1985 ( Fig. 1 ). The infected fish were accidentally found by the staff of the Hokkaido Fisheries Experimental Station at Kushiro and Muroran. Each copepod was carefully removed from each fresh host (body size not measured), fixed, and preserved in 70% ethanol. At the Aquaparasitology Laboratory, Shizuoka Prefecture , the specimens were examined using an Olympus SZX10 stereo microscope. All drawings were made with the aid of a drawing tube attached to the microscope. Morphological terminol-
© 2024 The Japanese Society of Systematic Zoology.

This is an open access article distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 License (CC BY, https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/), which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and ogy follows
who reported three nominal and one unidentified species of
Lophoura
from Japan . Voucher specimens have been deposited in the Crustacea collection of the National Museum of Nature and Science (NSMT-Cr), Tsukuba, Ibaraki Prefecture , Japan . The scientific and common names of fishes mentioned in this paper follow
.

mixed-citation.named-content: Rediscovery of a Deep-sea Fish Parasite Lophoura cornuta (Copepoda: Sphyriidae) in the Western North Pacific off Hokkaido, Northern Japan

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
Family
Sphyriidae C. B. Wilson, 1919
[New Japanese name: Uoyadori-soramame-mushi-ka] Genus
Lophoura Kӧlliker
in Gegenbaur, Kӧlliker, and Müller, 1853 [New Japanese name: Uoyadori-soramame-mushi-zoku]
Lophoura cornuta (C. B. Wilson, 1919 )
[New Japanese name: Irakoanago-yadori-soramame-mushi] (
)

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Rebelula cornuta C. B. Wilson, 1919: 582–585
, pl. 55, figs 46–53.
Excluded record.

Lophoura cornuta
:
Cohen 1973: 632
.
Material examined. Two post-metamorphic adult females (no attached males) (NSMT-Cr 31508 and 31509).
Site in host. Anterior part of body embedded in host (no detailed information on the attachment sites was obtained from the collectors).

Color. Yellow (
, ethanol-preserved specimens).

Japanese names. The new Japanese name of the family Sphyriidae is a combination of a Japanese adjective (“Uoyadori”) meaning fish-infecting and three Japanese nouns (“soramame-mushi-ka”), each meaning the shape of the trunk resembling a broad bean, a parasite, and a family. The new Japanese name of the genus
Lophoura
is similar to that of the family, but “zoku” means a genus. The first word (“Irakoanago”) in the new Japanese name of
L. cornuta
is the host name in Japanese.

Remarks. The morphological characters of the two post-metamorphic adult female specimens collected in this study correspond to the original description of
L. cornuta
by Wilson (1919) , and the specimens are herein identified as this species. A single post-metamorphic adult female with a male attached was used in the original description, and this female was 32 mm in TBL.

Currently, two types of enlarged processes (antennary and maxillary processes) have been reported to be present on the anterior surface of the cephalothorax in several species of
Lophoura
including
L. cornuta ( Sebone and Dippenaar 2023 )
. In the two adult female specimens examined in this study, two conical protuberances forming the antennary processes are found, but the maxillary processes are not clearly recognized (
,
).

Lophoura cornuta
is a poorly known fish parasite. There is only one paper on
L. cornuta
from Japan , which is the description of the species published more than 100 years ago ( Wilson 1919 ).
One of the two specimens reported herein was collected off Cape Shirepa , eastern Hokkaido (locality 2 in
)
. This locality is close to the type locality of
L. cornuta
, which is off Cape Ochiishi , eastern Hokkaido (locality 1 in
).

When
L. cornuta
was described by Wilson (1919) , the host fish was reported as “
Synaphobranchus affinis
”. However, three
Synaphobranchus species
(
S. affinis
,
S. kaupii
, and
S. brevidorsalis
) occur in the western North Pacific off northern Japan ( Matsubara and Ochiai 1951 ; Shinohara et al. 1996 , 2009 ), where
S . kaupii
predominates among these species ( Imamura et al. 1999 ; Watanabe 2014 ). Thus, it is possible that the host fish reported by Wilson (1919) was not
S. affinis
but
S. kaupii
.

Lophoura cornuta
was redescribed by Boxshall (1989) from three adult (two post-metamorphic and one metamorphosing) female specimens taken from a synaphobranchid eel
S. cf. brevidorsalis
in the western South Pacific off New Caledonia . The adult female specimens were much smaller (about 7.5 and 5.5 mm in TBL) than those of the Japanese adult female specimens (23.0– 43.7 mm in TBL) ( Wilson 1919 ; this paper). Although Boxshall (1989) stated that no significant differences were found between the New Caledonian material and that of Wilson (1919) , the cephalothorax of his specimens was, unlike that of the Japanese specimens (
,
; see also Wilson 1919 : pl. 55, fig. 46), smooth and not transversely wrinkled ( Boxshall 1989 : fig. 9A, B). Furthermore, the holdfast organ of his larger specimen possessed many, slender, branching, or simple processes ( Boxshall 1989 : fig. 9A), but that of the Japanese specimens has four trunks with some slender, elongated, irregularly curved branches of different lengths (
,
; see also Wilson 1919 : pl. 55, fig. 46). At present, it is unknown whether such morphological differences are due to local or body size-dependent intraspecific variations of
L. cornuta
, and specimens of about 10–20 mm in TBL are necessary to answer this question.

Recently, Sebone and Dippenaar (2023) reported the morphology of
L. cornuta
based on one adult female specimen ( 28.4 mm in TBL) taken from a hairy conger
B . albescens
in the Indian Ocean off the south coast of South Africa . As mentioned by these authors, the South African specimen differs from the western Pacific specimens reported by Wilson (1919) and Boxshall (1989) in the size and morphology of posterior processes: their specimen has posterior processes shorter than the trunk and cylinders (reported as stalks) extending laterally on the stalks (as peduncles) ( Sebone and Dippenaar 2023 : fig.7a), but the western Pacific specimens have posterior processes longer than or as long as the trunk and cylinders extending mostly posteriorly on the stalks ( Wilson 1919 : pl. 55, fig. 46; Boxshall 1989 : fig. 9A). In the present study, we have also confirmed these differences between our specimens (
,
) and the South African specimen. Moreover, the hosts reported from the western Pacific belong to the family Synaphobranchidae ( Wilson 1919 ; Boxshall 1989 ; this paper), whereas that from South Africa belongs to
Congridae ( Sebone and Dippenaar 2023 )
. According to Boxshall (1998) , each
Lophoura species
occurs on only one family of fish hosts. Therefore, from the viewpoint of the parasite’s morphology and host utilization, further taxonomic work is needed for the
Lophoura
copepod infecting the hairy conger off South Africa .

Slender codling
Halargyreus johnsonii Günther, 1862
( Gadiformes : Moridae ) is known to have an infection of “
Lophoura cornuta
” in the western North Atlantic and the Southern Ocean ( Cohen 1973 ). One of the specimens of this copepod was earlier reported as “a large parasitic copepod, tentatively assigned to the Caligoida” from a slender codling caught in the New York Bight ( Haedrich and Horn 1970 ). However, as stated above,
L. cornuta
usually infects synaphobranchid eels ( Wilson 1919 ; Boxshall 1989 ; this paper), and it is thus very likely that the parasitic copepod reported by Cohen (1973) from the morid fish (slender codling) is not
L. cornuta
but a different species. To date, two species of
Lophoura
(
L. magna Szidat, 1971
and
L. tetraphylla Ho, 1985
) have been reported from morid fishes ( Boxshall and Halsey 2004 ), and Patagonian codling
Lepidion ensiferus (Günther, 1887)
( Szidat 1971 , its scientific name misspelled as “
L . euriferus
”) and blue antimora
Antimora rostrata (Günther, 1878)
( Ho 1985 ; Hogans 1986 ) are the hosts of these two parasites, respectively. Cohen (1973) pointed out that the above “
L. euriferus
” is not
L. ensiferus
but
H . johnsonii
.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
The vertical distribution ranges of
Synaphobranchus spp.
are, for example, from 290–2334 m in grey cutthroat, 274–2869 m in Kaup’s arrowtooth eel, and 900–3000 m in shortdorsal cutthroat eel
S . brevidorsalis ( Sulak and Shcherbachev 1997 )
. In the western Pacific,
L. cornuta
was collect- ed from eels of the first two species at depths of 550–657 m off Japan (
; this paper) and from an eel resembling the third species (
S . cf. brevidorsalis
) at a depth of 970 m off New Caledonia (
), which indicates that the infected eels occurred on the continental slope. Moreover, deep-water arrowtooth eel, which belongs to a different genus
Histiobranchus Gill, 1883
, occurs in deeper waters, ranging from 731–4700 m , than
Synaphobranchus spp.
(
), and
L. simplex
was collected from a deep-water arrowtooth eel captured at a depth of 2567 m in the eastern North Atlantic (
).

Currently, using an ROV (remotely operated vehicle) equipped with two high-definition cameras,
Synaphobranchus spp.
were found infected by a sphyriid copepod in the western North Atlantic along the northeastern U.S. continental margin and New England Seamount Chain (
). These fish were observed at depths of 500–2025 m and most abundant at 1100–1400 m in depth. The sphyriid copepod was as large as up to 5 cm in total length and was found attached to the mid-body of the fish. The prevalence of its infection on
Synaphobranchus spp.
was quite low (0.64%) (only eight fish were infected out of 1241 fish observed). The copepod was suggested to be a species of
Lophoura
, but no species identification was made (
). Although
L. gracilis
has been reported from synaphobranchid eels in the western North Atlantic near the survey area (
;
), morphological information is necessary to identify the observed copepod because we know little about the sphyriid copepods in the survey area and other species of
Lophoura
might occur there.

To date, four accepted and one unidentified species of the genus
Lophoura
have been reported from deep-sea fishes in Japan , and all of these species, except
L. cornuta
infecting grey cutthroat and Kaup’s arrowtooth eel, are parasites of grenadiers and rattails ( Gadiformes : Macrouridae ). They are:
L. cardusa (Leigh-Sharpe, 1934)
from sujidara
Hymenocephalus striatissimus
Jordan and Gilbert, 1904;
L. ventricula Ho and Kim, 1989
from largenose grenadier
Coryphaenoides nasutus Günther, 1877
;
L. tetraloba Ho and Kim, 1989
from Japanese pugnose grenadier
Nezumia condylura
Jordan and Gilbert, 1904; and
Lophoura sp.
from kagamihige
Kumba japonica (Matsubara, 1943)
(reported as
Ventrifossa japonica
) (
). While
described a new species,
Rebelura kamoharai
, from sujidara caught in Tosa Bay, this copepod was later transferred to the genus
Lophoura ( Yamaguti 1963 )
but currently has been regarded as a junior synonym of
L. cardusa ( Ho and Kim 1989 )
. Moreover, according to
, their specimen of
Lophoura sp.
has three main processes on its cephalothoracic holdfast organ and appeared to be an undescribed species. However, as their specimen was young and non-ovigerous, they did not describe it as a new species. An identification key to the four nominal species of
Lophoura
reported from Japan is provided below based on
,
,
, and this paper.

mixed-citation.named-content: Rediscovery of a Deep-sea Fish Parasite Lophoura cornuta (Copepoda: Sphyriidae) in the Western North Pacific off Hokkaido, Northern Japan

tp:treatment-sec.p:
1. Stalks of posterior processes issuing from midventral surface of trunk.......
L. ventricula Ho and Kim, 1989
— Stalks of posterior processes issuing from near posterior margin of trunk............................. 2

2. Cephalothorax smooth..
L. cardusa (Leigh-Sharpe, 1934)
— Cephalothorax transversely wrinkled............... 3

3. Holdfast organ with four trunks, each with short and thick branch...........
L. tetraloba Ho and Kim, 1989

— Holdfast organ with four trunks, each with some slen- der, elongated, irregularly curved branches of different lengths...............
L. cornuta (C. B. Wilson, 1919 )

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: I thank T. Chad Walter, Department of Invertebrate Zoology, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C., and Masato Nitta, Nansei Field Station, Fisheries Technology Institute, Japan Fisheries Research and Education Agency, Minami- Ise, for their assistance with literature. I am also grateful to two anonymous reviewers and Hiroshi Yamasaki, the editor of the journal, for their comments on the manuscript of the paper.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Kazuya Nagasawa: Conceptualization; Resources; Formal Analysis; Investigation; Visualization; Writing – original draft; Writing – review & editing.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research has not received any specific grant from any funding agency, commercial or not-for-profit sector.

sec.title: Declarations
sec.p: Competing interests. The author declares no conflicts of interest.
